issue.body:

Cant bump`tiny` because it doenst work in my environment (React Native).

`xOnlyPointFromPoint`is needed by BIP47 (payment codes).

Is there any way to hack a pure-js implementation, or backport it to `v1` branch..?

Thanks!

issue.title: [Question] Can a mainnet wallet created with path: m/84'/1'/0'/0 work?
issue.body:
Hi thanks..

By mistake I have created a mainnet wallet with 1 as coin (but with network: bitcoin.networks.bitcoin) so it creates mainnet bitcoin addresses. (no funds on the wallets so no danger)

Is that wallet able to send bitcoin?

I think the answer is yes but I want to confirm.

Thanks.

issue.title: [Question] Can a mainnet wallet created with path: m/84'/1'/0'/0 work?
issue.body:
Hi thanks..

By mistake I have created a mainnet wallet with 1 as coin (but with network: bitcoin.networks.bitcoin) so it creates mainnet bitcoin addresses. (no funds on the wallets so no danger)

Is that wallet able to send bitcoin?

I think the answer is yes but I want to confirm.

Thanks.

comment.body:
Some wallets (like Electrum) have advanced features where you can specify any path for deriving addresses for any network.

So some wallets will always allow you to recover, but you need to know what you're doing.

This question is answered. Closing.

issue.title: "Double Spend Cancel" logic needs to be updated for new Bitcoin 24.0 feature
issue.body:
Bitcoin 24.0 adds a new [`mempoolfullrbf` option](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/release-notes/release-notes-24.0.md#notice-of-new-option-for-transaction-replacement-policies) that allows for replace-by-fee even if the original transaction didn't set the RBF flag.

Currently, the [`get_tx_info`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L762) and [`dscancel`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L2066) functions only consider a double-spend-cancel viable if the transaction has the RBF flag set (i.e. `if not tx.is_final()`).  
As the linked release notes mention, full RBF will now be a mainstream feature even though many alternate implementations have supported it for a while.  Either `is_final()` should always return False or it should depend on if the transaction has been confirmed or not.

comment.body:
From a usability perspective, what you really want to avoid is:

1. Electrum says we can cancel.
2. Electrum fails to cancel at a high rate due to lack of adoption of the mempoolfullrbf flag (currently defaults to off)

Maybe introduce the logic change as a simple flag that advanced users can toggle, and the default can be switched to "always return False" after the success rate is high enough (enough of the network adopts the mempoolfullrbf flag)

pull_request.title: Silent payments v1
pull_request.body:
### Silent Payments
> Receive private payments from anyone on a single static address without requiring any interaction or extra on-chain overhead.

More on `Silent Payments`:
 - https://gist.github.com/RubenSomsen/c43b79517e7cb701ebf77eec6dbb46b8
 - https://rumble.com/v12kuz7-bitcoin-silent-payments.html

`silent-payments.spec` contains a simple test for Silent Payments.

The purpose of this PR is: 
 - to see if this library can support such a construct and how it would look like (after `p2tr-v1` branch gets merged)
 - serve as a starting point for developers that want to add silent payments to their wallet
 - start a discussion on how `Silent Payments` should be constructed and check that this implementation is correct

This PR is not concerned on the scanning/detecting silent payments.

issue.title: Do real secp256k1 point->curve checking
issue.body:
* This is a breaking change, as it requires the JS environment to have BigInt (all supported releases that I can find do).
* This check may prevent loss of funds by eliminating a category of unspendable addresses from being created.
* Performance is almost as fast as tiny-secp256k1 39-42us vs 33-35us.

comment.body:
Not sure if I want to ask for a rebase (we merged taproot yay!!!) or just close this...

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

I will leave it rc for 2 weeks, and if we get no issues, I'll publish it as v6.1.0

pull_request.title: feat: add support for pay to taproot
pull_request.body:
## Summary
This is the first version for the `p2tr` payment. It is not complete, but it covers most of the functionality.
I'm opening this PR for others to test, review and provide feedback.
Main changes listed below:

### New payment type: `P2TR`
It follows the same approach as the other payments (`p2wsh`, `p2pkh`, ...)
- the `PaymentOpts` object takes an extra field: `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface`
  - this field is required for `P2TR` (but not for the other payment types)
  - `eccLib` is required for the tweak operations. The `ECC` logic has been extracted out of this lib.
- examples of how to use `P2TR` can be found in the unit tests and integration tests (see tests section)


### `Payment` interface
The `Payment` interface has 3 new fields:
 - `internalPubkey` - the internal key as defined by [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#constructing-and-spending-taproot-outputs). 
 - `scriptTree` - a Merkle tree whose leaves consist of a version number and a script (see [BIP341)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
 - `redeemVersion` - the version of the leaf being spent (if the script-path spend is used). Default value: `0xc0`

Some `Payment` fields have `taproot` specific meaning:
- `pubkey` - the tweaked `internalPubkey` as defined in [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
  - > is computed as P + hash(P||m)G for a public key P, and the root m of the Merkle tree
- `hash` - the hash of the root of the Merkle `scriptTree`. Empty if not `scriptTree` is used.
- `signature` - a Schnorr signature,  if key-path spent is used. Empty otherwise.
- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

### Tests
 - unit test data
   - `p2tr.json`: data generated using the bitcoin test framework [test/functional/wallet_taproot.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/functional/wallet_taproot.py)
   - `BIP341 test cases`: [Test vectors for scriptPubKey construction](https://github.com/sipa/bips/blob/202110_bip341_vectors/bip-0341/wallet-test-vectors.mediawiki) recommended [here](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2021-November/019587.html) by Pieter Wuille
 - integration tests (`test/integration/taproot.spec.ts`)
 - **script-path** spend on `testnet` ([code sample and transaction links](https://gist.github.com/motorina0/e6bb1b32b3d5d2fc80e1bd63d5efea4f))

### Further Comments
Note for reviewers: all `.js` files are generated, only the `.ts` files require review

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

comment.body:
> Any progress in this issue? AFAIK [iancoleman/bip39#507](https://github.com/iancoleman/bip39/issues/507) is waiting for this.

It's basically done... but we would like more eyes on it.
One more thorough review by someone and I'll feel better about merging it.

pull_request.title: Logs cleanup
pull_request.body:
Fixes https://github.com/mempool/mempool/issues/2332

I've added some tags for most important message but that's a work that will need to be continued over time. @softsimon @mononaut please use the new logger tags for your new logs (at least for >= INFO levels). You can find/add loggers tag in `Logger::tags` object, then you use use it like `logger.debug(`This is a LN related log`, logger.tags.ln);`

~@softsimon Do you have a better approach to store/use logger tags? For now I've just added them in [Logger.tags object](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-311a550eb2e3c2360d5611f3cad0e0170c755cf71b46094652c96e61f8c6ed92R35) and I use it like [```logger.info(`${logger.tags.ln} This is a test`);```](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-afe74c642a8770eaa6f6b83c0e207e308c2288b0b3c37a1b310d86bbf12631b2R22)~ Fixed

Also I moved lot of lightning spam log into `debug` and only kept `info` for getting progress update (every 30 seconds by default, configurable with `config.LIGHTNING.LOGGER_UPDATE_INTERVAL`) and also update on nodes/channels.

Example while running locally:

```
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> Starting Mempool Server... (c863a74)
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Restoring mempool and blocks data from disk cache
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> CLightning client connected
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Database connection established.
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Starting statistics service
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Starting currency rates service
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Currency rates service will be queried over clearnet using https://price.bisq.wiz.biz/getAllMarketPrices
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> Mempool Server is running on port 8999
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Updating latest mining pools from https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mempool/mining-pools/master/pools.json over clearnet
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Starting lightning network sync service
Nov 23 20:07:10 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Fetching daily price history from exchanges and saving missing ones into the database
Nov 23 20:07:16 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> [Mining] Inserted 1 daily historical prices into the db
Nov 23 20:07:16 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Fetching hourly price history from exchanges and saving missing ones into the database
Nov 23 20:07:22 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Indexing 8200 blocks from #754400 to #744401
Nov 23 20:07:30 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Starting closed channels scan for the first time
Nov 23 20:07:38 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Checking if channel has been closed 7713/111122
Nov 23 20:07:53 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> The mempool is now in sync!
Nov 23 20:08:08 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Checking if channel has been closed 18556/111122
Nov 23 20:08:39 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Checking if channel has been closed 30007/111122
```

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

comment.body:
It looks like GraphQL does not plan to support any binary formats: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/432

The best alternative would be: `bufferSignature.toString('base64')` and `Buffer.from(stringSignature, 'base64')`

For any object that might contain Buffers, I recommend https://www.npmjs.com/package/buffer-json (buffer-json is made by one of the bitcoinjs maintainers)

issue.title: [Feature/REST] Pagination by index for address|scripthash txs/chain endpoint
issue.body:
Mempool (which relies on this endpoint for its address pages) currently can only implement "next page" on the address page since there is no way to skip a certain number of transactions.

ie. If an address has 100 transactions, right now it shows the first 25 and you have to click "show more" and it fetches the next 25 with the last_seen_txid of the last tx on the current page.

With this patch, they can provide links numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, and clicking on 3 will pass `"50"` instead of the hex txid, which will skip the first 50 transactions and display starting from the 51st transaction.

If there are other endpoints you'd like to be index-paginated where they used to be hex id paginated, we can do something similar as well.

Just submitting my initial impl to get feedback.

comment.body:
> Is that so its possible to link directly to the Nth page instead of only the next/previous page?

This is precisely the feature we're looking for.

As a user with an address that has 100 pages of transactions, and I want to look for one of my first transactions, the current method requires skipping through 100 clicks and loads of the "next" button etc.

Whereas clicking a "last" or "99" button will just pass along 98 * 25 (2450) to the endpoint to get the transactions.

People who hit "next" or "2" when on "1" we can use the last seen feature as is. Usually people jumping 10-20 pages don't care if a transaction bumped everything down 1 while they reload, since clicking on "page 87" is not a precise window to begin with.
Out of curiosity, would cutting down on as_ref() calls increase performance at all?

pull_request.title: `Witness` API improvements
pull_request.body:
Cleanup PR to improve the `Witness` API by:
- Adding `Witness::from_slice()` and depreciating `Witness::from_vec()` methods (#1371).
- Making `Witness::push()` not generic and take in `&[u8]` instead of `AsRef<[u8]>` (#1372).

Note: `Witness::from_vec()` has been marked for depreciation from `0.30.0`. Let me know if this should be different.

pull_request.body:
# TODO
- [ ] Add API document.
- [ ] Add UI for posting to this endpoint. (Maybe similar to https://mempool.space/tx/push)

# Feature
Takes the PSBT as text/plain body, parses it, and adds the full parent transaction to each input that doesn't already have it. This is used for BTCPayServer / Trezor users which need access to the full parent transaction even with segwit inputs. It will respond with a text/plain PSBT in the same format (hex|base64).

Requested by @Kukks of BTCPay

comment.body:
Some wallets (like Electrum) have advanced features where you can specify any path for deriving addresses for any network.

So some wallets will always allow you to recover, but you need to know what you're doing.

This question is answered. Closing.

issue.title: "Double Spend Cancel" logic needs to be updated for new Bitcoin 24.0 feature
issue.body:
Bitcoin 24.0 adds a new [`mempoolfullrbf` option](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/release-notes/release-notes-24.0.md#notice-of-new-option-for-transaction-replacement-policies) that allows for replace-by-fee even if the original transaction didn't set the RBF flag.

Currently, the [`get_tx_info`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L762) and [`dscancel`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L2066) functions only consider a double-spend-cancel viable if the transaction has the RBF flag set (i.e. `if not tx.is_final()`).  
As the linked release notes mention, full RBF will now be a mainstream feature even though many alternate implementations have supported it for a while.  Either `is_final()` should always return False or it should depend on if the transaction has been confirmed or not.

comment.body:
From a usability perspective, what you really want to avoid is:

1. Electrum says we can cancel.
2. Electrum fails to cancel at a high rate due to lack of adoption of the mempoolfullrbf flag (currently defaults to off)

Maybe introduce the logic change as a simple flag that advanced users can toggle, and the default can be switched to "always return False" after the success rate is high enough (enough of the network adopts the mempoolfullrbf flag)

pull_request.title: Silent payments v1
pull_request.body:
### Silent Payments
> Receive private payments from anyone on a single static address without requiring any interaction or extra on-chain overhead.

More on `Silent Payments`:
 - https://gist.github.com/RubenSomsen/c43b79517e7cb701ebf77eec6dbb46b8
 - https://rumble.com/v12kuz7-bitcoin-silent-payments.html

`silent-payments.spec` contains a simple test for Silent Payments.

The purpose of this PR is: 
 - to see if this library can support such a construct and how it would look like (after `p2tr-v1` branch gets merged)
 - serve as a starting point for developers that want to add silent payments to their wallet
 - start a discussion on how `Silent Payments` should be constructed and check that this implementation is correct

This PR is not concerned on the scanning/detecting silent payments.

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

pull_request.title: feat: add support for pay to taproot
pull_request.body:
## Summary
This is the first version for the `p2tr` payment. It is not complete, but it covers most of the functionality.
I'm opening this PR for others to test, review and provide feedback.
Main changes listed below:

### New payment type: `P2TR`
It follows the same approach as the other payments (`p2wsh`, `p2pkh`, ...)
- the `PaymentOpts` object takes an extra field: `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface`
  - this field is required for `P2TR` (but not for the other payment types)
  - `eccLib` is required for the tweak operations. The `ECC` logic has been extracted out of this lib.
- examples of how to use `P2TR` can be found in the unit tests and integration tests (see tests section)


### `Payment` interface
The `Payment` interface has 3 new fields:
 - `internalPubkey` - the internal key as defined by [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#constructing-and-spending-taproot-outputs). 
 - `scriptTree` - a Merkle tree whose leaves consist of a version number and a script (see [BIP341)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
 - `redeemVersion` - the version of the leaf being spent (if the script-path spend is used). Default value: `0xc0`

Some `Payment` fields have `taproot` specific meaning:
- `pubkey` - the tweaked `internalPubkey` as defined in [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
  - > is computed as P + hash(P||m)G for a public key P, and the root m of the Merkle tree
- `hash` - the hash of the root of the Merkle `scriptTree`. Empty if not `scriptTree` is used.
- `signature` - a Schnorr signature,  if key-path spent is used. Empty otherwise.
- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

### Tests

   - `p2tr.json`: data generated using the bitcoin test framework [test/functional/wallet_taproot.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/functional/wallet_taproot.py)

## Summary
This is the first version for the `p2tr` payment. It is not complete, but it covers most of the functionality.
I'm opening this PR for others to test, review and provide feedback.
Main changes listed below:

### New payment type: `P2TR`
It follows the same approach as the other payments (`p2wsh`, `p2pkh`, ...)
- the `PaymentOpts` object takes an extra field: `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface`
  - this field is required for `P2TR` (but not for the other payment types)
  - `eccLib` is required for the tweak operations. The `ECC` logic has been extracted out of this lib.
- examples of how to use `P2TR` can be found in the unit tests and integration tests (see tests section)


### `Payment` interface
The `Payment` interface has 3 new fields:
 - `internalPubkey` - the internal key as defined by [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#constructing-and-spending-taproot-outputs). 
 - `scriptTree` - a Merkle tree whose leaves consist of a version number and a script (see [BIP341)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
 - `redeemVersion` - the version of the leaf being spent (if the script-path spend is used). Default value: `0xc0`

Some `Payment` fields have `taproot` specific meaning:
- `pubkey` - the tweaked `internalPubkey` as defined in [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
  - > is computed as P + hash(P||m)G for a public key P, and the root m of the Merkle tree
- `hash` - the hash of the root of the Merkle `scriptTree`. Empty if not `scriptTree` is used.
- `signature` - a Schnorr signature,  if key-path spent is used. Empty otherwise.
- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

comment.body:
> Any progress in this issue? AFAIK [iancoleman/bip39#507](https://github.com/iancoleman/bip39/issues/507) is waiting for this.

It's basically done... but we would like more eyes on it.
One more thorough review by someone and I'll feel better about merging it.

pull_request.title: Logs cleanup
pull_request.body:
Fixes https://github.com/mempool/mempool/issues/2332

I've added some tags for most important message but that's a work that will need to be continued over time. @softsimon @mononaut please use the new logger tags for your new logs (at least for >= INFO levels). You can find/add loggers tag in `Logger::tags` object, then you use use it like `logger.debug(`This is a LN related log`, logger.tags.ln);`

~@softsimon Do you have a better approach to store/use logger tags? For now I've just added them in [Logger.tags object](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-311a550eb2e3c2360d5611f3cad0e0170c755cf71b46094652c96e61f8c6ed92R35) and I use it like [```logger.info(`${logger.tags.ln} This is a test`);```](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-afe74c642a8770eaa6f6b83c0e207e308c2288b0b3c37a1b310d86bbf12631b2R22)~ Fixed

Also I moved lot of lightning spam log into `debug` and only kept `info` for getting progress update (every 30 seconds by default, configurable with `config.LIGHTNING.LOGGER_UPDATE_INTERVAL`) and also update on nodes/channels.

Example while running locally:

```
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> Starting Mempool Server... (c863a74)
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> Restoring mempool and blocks data from disk cache
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> CLightning client connected

Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> Mempool Server is running on port 8999
Nov 23 20:07:07 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Updating latest mining pools from https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mempool/mining-pools/master/pools.json over clearnet

Nov 23 20:07:10 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Fetching daily price history from exchanges and saving missing ones into the database
Nov 23 20:07:16 [8709] NOTICE: <lightning> [Mining] Inserted 1 daily historical prices into the db
Nov 23 20:07:16 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Fetching hourly price history from exchanges and saving missing ones into the database
Nov 23 20:07:22 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Mining] Indexing 8200 blocks from #754400 to #744401
Nov 23 20:07:30 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Starting closed channels scan for the first time
Nov 23 20:07:38 [8709] INFO: <lightning> [Lightning] Checking if channel has been closed 7713/111122

```

pull_request.body:
Fixes https://github.com/mempool/mempool/issues/2332

I've added some tags for most important message but that's a work that will need to be continued over time. @softsimon @mononaut please use the new logger tags for your new logs (at least for >= INFO levels). You can find/add loggers tag in `Logger::tags` object, then you use use it like `logger.debug(`This is a LN related log`, logger.tags.ln);`

~@softsimon Do you have a better approach to store/use logger tags? For now I've just added them in [Logger.tags object](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-311a550eb2e3c2360d5611f3cad0e0170c755cf71b46094652c96e61f8c6ed92R35) and I use it like [```logger.info(`${logger.tags.ln} This is a test`);```](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-afe74c642a8770eaa6f6b83c0e207e308c2288b0b3c37a1b310d86bbf12631b2R22)~ Fixed

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

comment.body:
It looks like GraphQL does not plan to support any binary formats: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/432

The best alternative would be: `bufferSignature.toString('base64')` and `Buffer.from(stringSignature, 'base64')`

For any object that might contain Buffers, I recommend https://www.npmjs.com/package/buffer-json (buffer-json is made by one of the bitcoinjs maintainers)

issue.title: [Feature/REST] Pagination by index for address|scripthash txs/chain endpoint
issue.body:
Mempool (which relies on this endpoint for its address pages) currently can only implement "next page" on the address page since there is no way to skip a certain number of transactions.

ie. If an address has 100 transactions, right now it shows the first 25 and you have to click "show more" and it fetches the next 25 with the last_seen_txid of the last tx on the current page.

With this patch, they can provide links numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, and clicking on 3 will pass `"50"` instead of the hex txid, which will skip the first 50 transactions and display starting from the 51st transaction.

If there are other endpoints you'd like to be index-paginated where they used to be hex id paginated, we can do something similar as well.

Just submitting my initial impl to get feedback.

comment.body:
> Is that so its possible to link directly to the Nth page instead of only the next/previous page?

This is precisely the feature we're looking for.

As a user with an address that has 100 pages of transactions, and I want to look for one of my first transactions, the current method requires skipping through 100 clicks and loads of the "next" button etc.

Whereas clicking a "last" or "99" button will just pass along 98 * 25 (2450) to the endpoint to get the transactions.

People who hit "next" or "2" when on "1" we can use the last seen feature as is. Usually people jumping 10-20 pages don't care if a transaction bumped everything down 1 while they reload, since clicking on "page 87" is not a precise window to begin with.
Out of curiosity, would cutting down on as_ref() calls increase performance at all?

pull_request.title: `Witness` API improvements
pull_request.body:
Cleanup PR to improve the `Witness` API by:
- Adding `Witness::from_slice()` and depreciating `Witness::from_vec()` methods (#1371).
- Making `Witness::push()` not generic and take in `&[u8]` instead of `AsRef<[u8]>` (#1372).

Note: `Witness::from_vec()` has been marked for depreciation from `0.30.0`. Let me know if this should be different.

issue.title: "Double Spend Cancel" logic needs to be updated for new Bitcoin 24.0 feature
issue.body:
Bitcoin 24.0 adds a new [`mempoolfullrbf` option](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/release-notes/release-notes-24.0.md#notice-of-new-option-for-transaction-replacement-policies) that allows for replace-by-fee even if the original transaction didn't set the RBF flag.

Currently, the [`get_tx_info`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L762) and [`dscancel`](https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/e8c5ff5d2d4b3ecf821baf0fb1880ece0e276d02/electrum/wallet.py#L2066) functions only consider a double-spend-cancel viable if the transaction has the RBF flag set (i.e. `if not tx.is_final()`).  
As the linked release notes mention, full RBF will now be a mainstream feature even though many alternate implementations have supported it for a while.  Either `is_final()` should always return False or it should depend on if the transaction has been confirmed or not.

comment.body:
From a usability perspective, what you really want to avoid is:

1. Electrum says we can cancel.
2. Electrum fails to cancel at a high rate due to lack of adoption of the mempoolfullrbf flag (currently defaults to off)

Maybe introduce the logic change as a simple flag that advanced users can toggle, and the default can be switched to "always return False" after the success rate is high enough (enough of the network adopts the mempoolfullrbf flag)

pull_request.title: Silent payments v1
pull_request.body:
### Silent Payments
> Receive private payments from anyone on a single static address without requiring any interaction or extra on-chain overhead.

More on `Silent Payments`:
 - https://gist.github.com/RubenSomsen/c43b79517e7cb701ebf77eec6dbb46b8
 - https://rumble.com/v12kuz7-bitcoin-silent-payments.html

`silent-payments.spec` contains a simple test for Silent Payments.

The purpose of this PR is: 
 - to see if this library can support such a construct and how it would look like (after `p2tr-v1` branch gets merged)
 - serve as a starting point for developers that want to add silent payments to their wallet
 - start a discussion on how `Silent Payments` should be constructed and check that this implementation is correct

This PR is not concerned on the scanning/detecting silent payments.

issue.title: Do real secp256k1 point->curve checking
issue.body:
* This is a breaking change, as it requires the JS environment to have BigInt (all supported releases that I can find do).
* This check may prevent loss of funds by eliminating a category of unspendable addresses from being created.
* Performance is almost as fast as tiny-secp256k1 39-42us vs 33-35us.

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

Published `v6.1.0-rc.0`!!!!!

Thanks to @motorina0 for the great work and thanks to everyone who helped review the large PR.

I will leave it rc for 2 weeks, and if we get no issues, I'll publish it as v6.1.0

pull_request.title: feat: add support for pay to taproot
pull_request.body:
## Summary
This is the first version for the `p2tr` payment. It is not complete, but it covers most of the functionality.
I'm opening this PR for others to test, review and provide feedback.
Main changes listed below:

### New payment type: `P2TR`
It follows the same approach as the other payments (`p2wsh`, `p2pkh`, ...)
- the `PaymentOpts` object takes an extra field: `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface`
  - this field is required for `P2TR` (but not for the other payment types)
  - `eccLib` is required for the tweak operations. The `ECC` logic has been extracted out of this lib.
- examples of how to use `P2TR` can be found in the unit tests and integration tests (see tests section)


### `Payment` interface
The `Payment` interface has 3 new fields:
 - `internalPubkey` - the internal key as defined by [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#constructing-and-spending-taproot-outputs). 
 - `scriptTree` - a Merkle tree whose leaves consist of a version number and a script (see [BIP341)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
 - `redeemVersion` - the version of the leaf being spent (if the script-path spend is used). Default value: `0xc0`

Some `Payment` fields have `taproot` specific meaning:
- `pubkey` - the tweaked `internalPubkey` as defined in [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
  - > is computed as P + hash(P||m)G for a public key P, and the root m of the Merkle tree
- `hash` - the hash of the root of the Merkle `scriptTree`. Empty if not `scriptTree` is used.
- `signature` - a Schnorr signature,  if key-path spent is used. Empty otherwise.
- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

### Tests
 - unit test data
   - `p2tr.json`: data generated using the bitcoin test framework [test/functional/wallet_taproot.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/functional/wallet_taproot.py)
   - `BIP341 test cases`: [Test vectors for scriptPubKey construction](https://github.com/sipa/bips/blob/202110_bip341_vectors/bip-0341/wallet-test-vectors.mediawiki) recommended [here](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2021-November/019587.html) by Pieter Wuille
 - integration tests (`test/integration/taproot.spec.ts`)
 - **script-path** spend on `testnet` ([code sample and transaction links](https://gist.github.com/motorina0/e6bb1b32b3d5d2fc80e1bd63d5efea4f))

### Further Comments
Note for reviewers: all `.js` files are generated, only the `.ts` files require review

- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

### Tests
 - unit test data
   - `p2tr.json`: data generated using the bitcoin test framework [test/functional/wallet_taproot.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/functional/wallet_taproot.py)
   - `BIP341 test cases`: [Test vectors for scriptPubKey construction](https://github.com/sipa/bips/blob/202110_bip341_vectors/bip-0341/wallet-test-vectors.mediawiki) recommended [here](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2021-November/019587.html) by Pieter Wuille
 - integration tests (`test/integration/taproot.spec.ts`)
 - **script-path** spend on `testnet` ([code sample and transaction links](https://gist.github.com/motorina0/e6bb1b32b3d5d2fc80e1bd63d5efea4f))

### Further Comments
Note for reviewers: all `.js` files are generated, only the `.ts` files require review

issue.title: feat: add support for pay to taproot
issue.body:
## Summary
This is the first version for the `p2tr` payment. It is not complete, but it covers most of the functionality.
I'm opening this PR for others to test, review and provide feedback.
Main changes listed below:

### New payment type: `P2TR`
It follows the same approach as the other payments (`p2wsh`, `p2pkh`, ...)
- the `PaymentOpts` object takes an extra field: `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface`
  - this field is required for `P2TR` (but not for the other payment types)
  - `eccLib` is required for the tweak operations. The `ECC` logic has been extracted out of this lib.
- examples of how to use `P2TR` can be found in the unit tests and integration tests (see tests section)


### `Payment` interface
The `Payment` interface has 3 new fields:
 - `internalPubkey` - the internal key as defined by [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#constructing-and-spending-taproot-outputs). 
 - `scriptTree` - a Merkle tree whose leaves consist of a version number and a script (see [BIP341)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
 - `redeemVersion` - the version of the leaf being spent (if the script-path spend is used). Default value: `0xc0`

Some `Payment` fields have `taproot` specific meaning:
- `pubkey` - the tweaked `internalPubkey` as defined in [BIP341](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0341.mediawiki#design)
  - > is computed as P + hash(P||m)G for a public key P, and the root m of the Merkle tree
- `hash` - the hash of the root of the Merkle `scriptTree`. Empty if not `scriptTree` is used.
- `signature` - a Schnorr signature,  if key-path spent is used. Empty otherwise.
- `redeem.output` - the leaf script, for `script-path` spends

### Taproot Helpers
- taproot related logic has been extracted to `ts_src/payment/taprootutils.ts`
- in the future it might be moved to a `bip341` module. See https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/issues/1780

### Address
- add stricter rules for Taproot (data size 32 and public key valid x-only coordinate)
- `from|toOutputScript`  takes in an optional `eccLib`. If missing, then it skips the `p2tr` matching falls down to the final Error

### PSBT
- it can now add Taproot inputs and outputs
- for the `key-path` spend the signer has to be tweaked (it does **not** perform the tweak internally)
- for the `script-path` spend a custom finalizer (`FinalScriptsFunc`) is **required** when a Taproot input is finalized. See `test/psbt.utils.ts` for such an example
- `PsbtOptsOptional` has a new field `eccLib?: TinySecp256k1Interface;`. `eccLib` is required if the PSBT instance uses taproot ins/outs
- the `Signer` interface has a new method: `signSchnorr?(hash: Buffer): Buffer;`. This method is required if a Taproot UTXO is being spent.

### Tests
 - unit test data
   - `p2tr.json`: data generated using the bitcoin test framework [test/functional/wallet_taproot.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/functional/wallet_taproot.py)
   - `BIP341 test cases`: [Test vectors for scriptPubKey construction](https://github.com/sipa/bips/blob/202110_bip341_vectors/bip-0341/wallet-test-vectors.mediawiki) recommended [here](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2021-November/019587.html) by Pieter Wuille
 - integration tests (`test/integration/taproot.spec.ts`)
 - **script-path** spend on `testnet` ([code sample and transaction links](https://gist.github.com/motorina0/e6bb1b32b3d5d2fc80e1bd63d5efea4f))

### Further Comments
Note for reviewers: all `.js` files are generated, only the `.ts` files require review

issue.title: TODO: Add Tapscript / Taproot feature
issue.body:
This will be a place to brainstorm ideas...

Needs:

1. Tagged Hashes (maybe make a smaller separate package)
2. Taproot builder (can we wedge this into the existing Payments API??? it seems to act similar to p2sh and p2wsh, and the lazy-loading should help greatly with performance due to the crypto operations to calculate the tweaked pubkey)
3. Segwit v1 Address generation via the Payments(Taproot) API
4. Schnorr signing module. (Modify tiny-secp256k1... not sure what to do with native JS though.)

Questions:

1. When should this be implemented? I'm guessing we should wait for at least a testnet release of Taproot before spending time on it... But at the same time, it would help the development of taproot if we can look at taproot with fresh eyes / a new perspective and make suggestions based on problems while implementing.
2. This is going to be a pretty big change... so maybe it should be a major version bump and that way we can reconsider existing API structure when adding Taproot.

Thoughts and comments welcome.

pull_request.body:
Fixes https://github.com/mempool/mempool/issues/2332

I've added some tags for most important message but that's a work that will need to be continued over time. @softsimon @mononaut please use the new logger tags for your new logs (at least for >= INFO levels). You can find/add loggers tag in `Logger::tags` object, then you use use it like `logger.debug(`This is a LN related log`, logger.tags.ln);`

~@softsimon Do you have a better approach to store/use logger tags? For now I've just added them in [Logger.tags object](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-311a550eb2e3c2360d5611f3cad0e0170c755cf71b46094652c96e61f8c6ed92R35) and I use it like [```logger.info(`${logger.tags.ln} This is a test`);```](https://github.com/mempool/mempool/pull/2339/files#diff-afe74c642a8770eaa6f6b83c0e207e308c2288b0b3c37a1b310d86bbf12631b2R22)~ Fixed

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

issue.title: [Question]How to encode a signature
issue.body:
Hi. My website uses graphql-apollo to send and receive information and signatures and everything are encoded ok with apollo-client.

But I am writing jest tests on the server so I am using node library "fetch" to send the graphql calls to the server.

When tyring to send an object with tx signatures I get errors.

What would be the equivalent  toBase64 & fromBase64 methods for just a signature?
And for any object?

Thanks.

comment.body:
It looks like GraphQL does not plan to support any binary formats: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/432

The best alternative would be: `bufferSignature.toString('base64')` and `Buffer.from(stringSignature, 'base64')`

For any object that might contain Buffers, I recommend https://www.npmjs.com/package/buffer-json (buffer-json is made by one of the bitcoinjs maintainers)

issue.title: [Feature/REST] Pagination by index for address|scripthash txs/chain endpoint
issue.body:
Mempool (which relies on this endpoint for its address pages) currently can only implement "next page" on the address page since there is no way to skip a certain number of transactions.

ie. If an address has 100 transactions, right now it shows the first 25 and you have to click "show more" and it fetches the next 25 with the last_seen_txid of the last tx on the current page.

With this patch, they can provide links numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, and clicking on 3 will pass `"50"` instead of the hex txid, which will skip the first 50 transactions and display starting from the 51st transaction.

If there are other endpoints you'd like to be index-paginated where they used to be hex id paginated, we can do something similar as well.

Just submitting my initial impl to get feedback.

comment.body:
> Is that so its possible to link directly to the Nth page instead of only the next/previous page?

This is precisely the feature we're looking for.

As a user with an address that has 100 pages of transactions, and I want to look for one of my first transactions, the current method requires skipping through 100 clicks and loads of the "next" button etc.

Whereas clicking a "last" or "99" button will just pass along 98 * 25 (2450) to the endpoint to get the transactions.

People who hit "next" or "2" when on "1" we can use the last seen feature as is. Usually people jumping 10-20 pages don't care if a transaction bumped everything down 1 while they reload, since clicking on "page 87" is not a precise window to begin with.
Out of curiosity, would cutting down on as_ref() calls increase performance at all?

pull_request.title: `Witness` API improvements
pull_request.body:
Cleanup PR to improve the `Witness` API by:
- Adding `Witness::from_slice()` and depreciating `Witness::from_vec()` methods (#1371).
- Making `Witness::push()` not generic and take in `&[u8]` instead of `AsRef<[u8]>` (#1372).

Note: `Witness::from_vec()` has been marked for depreciation from `0.30.0`. Let me know if this should be different.

pull_request.title: Feature: Add endpoint for PSBT nonWitnessUtxo inclusion
pull_request.body:
# TODO
- [ ] Add API document.
- [ ] Add UI for posting to this endpoint. (Maybe similar to https://mempool.space/tx/push)

# Feature
Takes the PSBT as text/plain body, parses it, and adds the full parent transaction to each input that doesn't already have it. This is used for BTCPayServer / Trezor users which need access to the full parent transaction even with segwit inputs. It will respond with a text/plain PSBT in the same format (hex|base64).

Requested by @Kukks of BTCPay
